FacilityName: Boar's Head Provisions Co., Inc. - Jarratt

_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: MI Inspection for High Pressure Receiver #2
MI inspection for High Pressure Receiver #2

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
1.1.	General
This Risk Management Program is designed to comply with the Environmental Protection Agency regulations detailed in 40 CFR Part 68.  The stationary source is the ammonia refrigeration system owned and operated by Boars Head Provisions Co., Inc.  Jarratt. The only RMP regulated substance at this facility is anhydrous ammonia--which is classified as a toxic substance, liquefied under pressure. 
This is an existing food processing facility.  The 2 refrigeration system(s) in this facility have an inventory approximately 59,249 pounds of anhydrous ammonia. The processes do not meet the requirements of Program 1. They are subject to OSHAs PSM standard.  Therefore, this RMP is written to meet the EPA Program 3 level of compliance.
Figure 1. Local area map of Jarratt facility. 

         




1.2		Accidental Release Prevention Policy
This facility follows a rigorous fourteen volume Process Safety Program to prevent the accidental release of ammonia. This RMP also addresses the PSM program in compliance with Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), Process Safety Management (PSM) of 29 CFR 1910.119. Employees and management participate and cooperate in the both process safety programs to maintain a work environment that is safe to employees, the community, and the environment.

1.3		Emergency Response Policy
The facility has a comprehensive emergency response plan that meets established criteria. 


1.4		Process Overview 
System 1 (ER-4) Overview: 
PROCESS & PROCESS CHEMISTRY
The process is the standard refrigeration cycle. It uses anhydrous ammonia as the refrigerant. The only substance inside the refrigeration system is ammonia. 
The process causes the ammonia to boil into a gas and then cool into a liquid and then repeats the process.  The refrigeration system lowers the liquid pressure to lower the boiling point and then evaporates the ammonia within the system using room air as the heat source. It then compresses the ammoni

a into a high pressure/temperature and cools the gas until it condenses. The condensed liquid flows to a low pressure part of the system where the pressure is lowered and the cycle starts all over.  The ammonia changes state from a liquid to a gas and back to a liquid. It does not chemically change; it is not consumed and does not wear out. It continuously circulates throughout the system.

CAPACITY
This food distribution facility operates a single temperature anhydrous ammonia (R-717) refrigeration system with engine room compressor capacities of approximately 2550 TR at (+24?F) and an evaporator load of approximately 1700 TR at (+24?F) suction temperature (high temp. system). 

SYSTEM CLASSIFICATION
This refrigeration system is a liquid recirculation system and is designed to operate at an over-feed ratio of approximately 3:1 for all evaporators. Anhydrous ammonia (R-717) refrigerant is a Group II refrigerant. Rotary screw compressors are used in the refrigeration system.
Engine room #4s electrical classification is Non-Hazardous or Ordinary based on the Mechanical Ventilation System and Ammonia detection meeting requirements. The Ventilation calculations and analysis are located in Volume #2 (Process Safety Information).
SYSTEM TEMPERATURES
This ammonia refrigeration system contains several interconnected sub-systems:
1.	High-temp. recirculating system(+24?F @ 38.0 psig)
2.	Compressor high temp. system (+24?F @ 38.0 psig)
3.	High-pressure receiver system(+90?F @ 165 psig)
4.	Condenser system (+90?F @ 165 psig)

SYSTEM STAGES
This system operates with one stage of compression providing one suction pressure for the refrigeration temperatures. 
ENGINE ROOM 4
Major equipment located inside the engine room includes:
	One high-stage compressor (Frick model RWBII-222/ 539.6 TR@+24?F / 450 HP).
	Three high-stage compressors (Frick model RWFII-270 / 671 TR@+24?F / 687 HP) one equipped with a variable frequency drive (C11).
	One 60 dia. X 16- 0 Vertical High Press

ure Receiver (231.2 cu. ft. @ 80%)
	One 54 dia. X 8- 0 Horizontal Thermosyphon Receiver (54.3 cu. ft. @ 50%)
	One 96 dia. X 14-3 Vertical Recirculator #2 (504.6 cu.ft. @ 80%) +24?F
	One Refrigerating Specialties Auto-Purger.

OUTSIDE ENGINE ROOMS
Major equipment located outside includes: 
	Four Frick Condensers Model XLP2-1224-1139 455.9 TR each @ +90?F
HIGH-PRESSURE RECEIVER
The high-pressure receiver is a vertical vessel. The volume of vessel HPR-1 (V-1) at maximum allowable liquid level (80% of total vessel volume) is 231.2 cu-ft. It operates at a saturated liquid temperature of +90°F. The high-pressure receiver stores the ammonia liquid coming from the condenser. Liquid from the condenser flows through this vessel after going through the Thermosyphon Receiver. High-pressure liquid is fed from this vessel to the rest of the system. 
THERMOSYPHON PILOT RECEIVER
The thermosyphon pilot-receiver, TSPR-1(V-3), is a horizontal high-pressure vessel. It is sized and used for storing a minimum five-minute supply of liquid ammonia for oil cooling and for separating liquid out of the return flow of ammonia from the thermosyphon oil coolers. The liquid volume in this vessel at normal operating level (50% of total vessel volume) is 54.3 cu.ft. at saturated liquid temperature of +90°F. All liquid from the condenser flows through this vessel then to High Pressure Receiver (V-1). The thermos-syphon oil coolers on the screw compressors C-7, C-11, C-12, and C-13 are fed from this vessel and return a liquid/gas mix back through the thermosyphon return piping. This Vessel has connection with the Condensers, High Pressure Receiver and Compressors 7 and 11-13.

+24°F HIGH-TEMPERATURE RECIRCULATOR  
The +24°F Re-circulator is a vertical pressure vessel. The volume of this vessel, RECIRC #2(V-2), at maximum allowable liquid level (80% of total vessel volume) is 504.6 cubic feet. It operates at a saturated liquid temperature of +24°F. The high temp. liquid is pumped from this v

essel to the production and storage air units where thirty- percent of the liquid mass is evaporated. The liquid-vapor mixture is returned to this vessel where the liquid is separated from the vapor. The compressors take the ammonia vapor from this vessel and compress it to approximately 165 psig. This vessel has connection with the compressors (dry suction) and with the pumped liquid and the high-temp wet suction piping from the evaporators.

CONDENSERS
The evaporative condensers use axial fans in a blow-through configuration. High-pressure ammonia vapor flows from the high-temperature compressors to the evaporative condenser where heat is removed, condensing the vapor to a high-pressure liquid. High-pressure liquid from the condenser is drained into the Thermosyphon Receiver then the high-pressure receiver. Saturated condensing temperature is 90°F (165.0 PSIG) at a corresponding 76°F WB. The condenser has connections with the compressor discharge line and the condenser drain lines go to the Thermosyphon Pilot Receiver (V-3).
PURGER
This system incorporates an automatic gas purger for removing non-condensable gases from the ammonia system. The presence of non-condensable gases in the condenser penalizes the system performance through the artificial elevation of condensing pressure. The non-condensable gases add their partial pressures to the ammonia partial pressure against which the compressors must pump. The system has several purge point connections, typically at each of the condenser liquid outlet pipes. 
HOT GAS DEFROST                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          
The compressor discharge hot gas is used to defrost the evaporators. During the defrost cycle, the hot gas refrigerant

gives up heat and condenses. With the fans shut down, the ability of the coil to transfer that heat to the air is severely limited. Thus, the heat from the hot gas is absorbed by metal in the coil. As the metal absorbs heat, its temperature rises. Once the surface temperature is high enough, any ice and/or frost on the coil surface will melt and drain off. Defrosting the evaporators occurs automatically on a time sequence by individual sequence timers or the computer.
EVAPORATORS 
In this facility, the evaporators are fed from liquid pumps. The feed rate is approximately 3:1. This system will circulate three times the amount of the refrigerant needed by the evaporator for the rated capacity. The +24°F high-temperature system includes the tempering cooler, frank packaging foyer, inedible 2, frankfurter packaging, tree wash, ham packing, Bologna Kitchen, head cheese, massage room, injection room, raw meat/ham receiving, pickle room, standardization cooler, product staging area, pack off, new packaging area, shipping dock, frank pack off, lay-down cooler, frankfurter area, Ham Pack 2 Receiving, frankfurter chiller, attic, smokehouse alley 1,2, & 3, frankfurter raw entrance the maintenance shop, +38 Raw Storage Cooler, +38 Receiving Dock, New +38 Boxing Room, New +75 Boxing Mezzanine, New +38 Pass Thru, New +75 Bin Wash, Pulled Pork, Ham Pack 2 Processing, Ham Pack 2 Cure Cooler, Ham Pack 2 pickle chiller, and R&D Test Area.
AMMONIA PIPING AND VALVES
The ammonia piping and valves in the system are labeled. The identification system is recognized by IIAR. P&ID prints are available for review. Pipe, fittings, and connections specifications for ammonia refrigeration systems shall meet or exceed ASME/ANSI B31.5 specifications.
SYSTEM SAFETIES
The ammonia system includes safeties to provide for emergency relief of overpressure, detection equipment in the event of a release of ammonia, automatic control of the Engine Room vent fans and remote compressor shutdown capability.

Each compressor vessel has a dual relief valve assembly which will relieve an overpressure in excess of 300 PSI.  A relief pressure of 300 PSI is relieved into a diffusion tank for C-7, C-11, C-12, and C-13. Compressors C-7, C-11, C-12, and C-13 oil coolers have a reseating relief regulator which vents back to the TSR line.
Relief valves for the vessels are located at the top of the ammonia vessels which will relieve an overpressure in excess of 225 or 250 PSI depending on the vessel. (refer to the Safety Relief Valve list). Relief valves on vessels in Engine Room #4 relieve to a diffusion tank all other vessels relieve to the atmosphere.
Ammonia detectors are located in the following areas and alarm to the Mystic monitoring system:
Engine Room #4 (1)
Engine Room #4 Vent Line (1)
Liverwurst MAU 6D (1)
Tree Wash MAU 8B (1)
Bologna Kitchen MAU 12C (1)
Stitch Pump MAU 15C (1)
Packaging RTE MAU 26B (1)
Packaging RTE MAU 35A (1)


The Engine Room vent fans will turn on in the event of ammonia detection in the Engine Rooms, or if the break glass button outside the Engine Rooms is activated. The fan can be controlled within the mystic panel from a computer as well.
Should it become necessary to shut down all the compressors there is a break glass button (Emergency Refrigeration Stop) located next to the Emergency Fan/Ventilation Start button outside the Engine Rooms that will shut down all the compressors and ammonia pumps when activated. For Engine Room #4 there is a Emergency Crossover Valve break glass button which will equalize the pressure from the High Pressure Receiver (V-1) to the Recirculator #2 (V-2).

System 2 (ER-3) Overview: 
PROCESS & PROCESS CHEMISTRY
The process is the standard refrigeration cycle. It uses anhydrous ammonia as the refrigerant. The only substance inside the refrigeration system is ammonia. 
The process causes the ammonia to boil into a gas and then cool into a liquid and then repeats the process.  The refrigeration system lowers the li

quid pressure to lower the boiling point and then evaporates the ammonia within the system using room air as the heat source. It then compresses the ammonia into a high pressure/temperature and cools the gas until it condenses. The condensed liquid flows to a low pressure part of the system where the pressure is lowered and the cycle starts all over. The ammonia changes state from a liquid to a gas and back to a liquid. It does not chemically change; it is not consumed and does not wear out. It continuously circulates throughout the system.

CAPACITY
This food distribution facility operates a one temperature, single-stage, anhydrous ammonia (R-717) refrigeration system with engine room compressor capacities of approximately 1174 TR @ +14?F suction temperature and an evaporator load of approximately 928 TR @ +14?F suction temperature.
SYSTEM CLASSIFICATION
This refrigeration system is a liquid recirculation system and is designed to operate at an over-feed ratio of approximately 3:1 for all evaporators. Anhydrous ammonia (R-717) refrigerant is a Group II refrigerant. Rotary screw compressors are used in the refrigeration system.
Engine room #3s electrical classification is Non-Hazardous or Ordinary based on the Mechanical Ventilation System and Ammonia detection meeting requirements. The Ventilation calculations and analysis are located in Volume #2 (Process Safety Information).
SYSTEM TEMPERATURES	
This ammonia refrigeration system contains five interconnected sub-systems:
5.	Thermospyhon Pilot Receiver (+90°F @ 165 psig).
6.	High temperature re-circulating system (+14?F @ 27.5 psig).
7.	Compressor high-temperature system (+14?F @ 27.5 psig).
8.	High-pressure receiver system (90?F @ 165 psig).
9.	Condenser system (90?F C.T. 76°F W.B.)
SYSTEM STAGES
This system operates with one stage of compression providing one suction pressure for the refrigeration temperatures. 
ENGINE ROOM
Major equipment located inside the engine room includes: 
	One Frick model RWFII-270 c

ompressor / 505.9 TR @ +14?F 
	One Frick model RWF-134H compressor / 250.0 TR @ +14?F
	One Frick model RWF-222H compressor / 418.0 TR @ +14?F
	One 72" dia. X 16'-6" vertical high-pressure receiver (341.5 cu. ft. @ 80%)
	One 84" dia. X 10'- 4" vertical re-circulator package (269.4 cu. ft. @ 80%)  +14?F.
	One 36" dia. X 7'- 0 thermosyphon pilot receiver at (21.7 cu. ft. @ 80%) +90?F.
	One Transfer Vessel (4.7 cu. ft. @ 80%)

OUTSIDE ENGINE ROOM
	One IMECO XLP-XL-870 condenser heat rejection-(12,789 MBH) @ +95?FCT / 76?FWB.
	One FRICK XLP2-1224-1196-1 condenser heat rejection-(10,277 MBH) @ +95?FCT / 76?FWB.

THERMOSYPHON PILOT RECEIVER
The thermosyphon pilot-receiver, TSPR-2, is a horizontal high-pressure vessel. It is sized and used for storing a minimum five-minute supply of liquid ammonia for oil cooling and for separating liquid out of the return flow of ammonia from the thermosyphon oil coolers. The liquid volume in this vessel at normal operating level (50% of total vessel volume) is 21.7 cu-ft at saturated liquid temperature of +90°F. All liquid from the condenser flows through this vessel. The thermosyphon oil coolers on the screw compressors are fed from this vessel and return a liquid/gas mix back through the thermosyphon return piping. All of the liquid ammonia from the condenser drains through this receiver to the high pressure receiver. This Vessel has connection with the Condensers, High Pressure Receiver and Compressors 8-10.

HIGH-PRESSURE RECEIVER
The high-pressure receiver is a vertical vessel. The volume of vessel HPR-2 at maximum allowable liquid level (80% of total vessel volume) is 341.5 cu-ft. It operates at a saturated liquid temperature of +90°F. The high-pressure receiver stores the ammonia liquid coming from the condenser after going through the Thermosyphon Receiver. High-pressure liquid is fed from this vessel to the rest of the system. 
+14°F HIGH-TEMPERATURE RECIRCULATOR 
The re-circulator is a vertical pressure vessel. The volu

me of this vessel, RECIRC #5, at maximum allowable liquid level (80% of total vessel volume) is 269.4 cubic feet. It operates at a saturated liquid temperature of +14°F. The high temp. liquid is pumped from this vessel to the production and storage air units where thirty- percent of the liquid mass is evaporated. The liquid-vapor mixture is returned to this vessel where the liquid is separated from the vapor. The compressors take the ammonia vapor from this vessel and compress it to approximately 165 psig. This vessel has connection with the compressors (dry suction) and with the pumped liquid and the high-temp wet suction piping from the evaporators and chiller and the liquid transfer vessel (LT-1).
LIQUID TRANSFER VESSEL
The liquid transfer vessel, LT-1, is used to move excess ammonia liquid from the re-circulator back to the High-Pressure Receiver. It is a vertical pressure vessel with a maximum allowable liquid volume of 4.7 cubic feet at 80% of total vessel volume. After liquid drains from the re-circulator, hot gas raises the pressure in this vessel to high-side pressure and a small 1 HP pump pushes the liquid into the HPR. This vessel has connection with the Recirculator, HPR, and hot gas piping.
CONDENSERS
The evaporative condensers use axial fans in a blow-through configuration. High-pressure ammonia vapor flows from the high-temperature compressors to the evaporative condenser where heat is removed, condensing the vapor to a high-pressure liquid. High-pressure liquid from the condenser is drained into the Thermosyphon Receiver then the high-pressure receiver. Saturated condensing temperature is 90°F (165 PSIG) at a corresponding 76°F WB. The condenser has connections with the compressor discharge line and the condenser drain lines go to the thermosyphon receiver.
PURGER
This system incorporates an automatic gas purger for removing non-condensable gases from the ammonia system. The presence of non-condensable gases in the condenser penalizes the system perf

ormance through the artificial elevation of condensing pressure. The non-condensable gases add their partial pressures to the ammonia partial pressure against which the compressors must pump. The system has several purge point connections, typically at each of the condenser liquid outlet pipes. 
HOT GAS DEFROST
The compressor discharge hot gas is used to defrost the evaporators. During the defrost cycle, the hot gas refrigerant gives up heat and condenses. With the fans shut down, the ability of the coil to transfer that heat to the air is severely limited. Thus, the heat from the hot gas is absorbed by metal in the coil. As the metal absorbs heat, its temperature rises. Once the surface temperature is high enough, any ice and/or frost on the coil surface will melt and drain off. Defrosting the evaporators occurs automatically on a time sequence by individual sequence timers.
EVAPORATORS 
In this facility, the evaporators are fed from liquid pumps. The feed rate is approximately 3:1. This system will circulate three times the amount of the refrigerant needed by the evaporator for the rated capacity. The +14°F high-temperature system includes the 16 air units for the 4 equalization coolers, 14 blast chillers, the smokehouse rooftop unit, the bologna staging cooler, semi-jet chiller, Ice-Maker and GC-2 is fed with high pressure liquid for cooling of the Vyper drive on Compressor #8.
AMMONIA PIPING AND VALVES
The ammonia piping and valves in the system are labeled. The identification system is recognized by IIAR. P&ID prints are available for review. Pipe, fittings, and connections specifications for ammonia refrigeration systems shall meet or exceed ASME/ANSI B31.5 specifications.
SYSTEM SAFETIES
The ammonia system includes safeties to provide for emergency relief of overpressure, detection equipment in the event of a release of ammonia, automatic control of the Engine Room vent fans and remote compressor shutdown capability.
Each compressor vessel has a dual relief v

alve assembly which will relieve an overpressure in excess of 300 & 250 PSI; (C8-300psi) (C-9, C-10- 250psi) to a line or lines vented to the outside.    The Compressors C-8, C-9, and C-10 oil coolers have a reseating relief regulator which vents back to the TSR line.
Relief valves for the vessels are located at the top of the ammonia vessels which will relieve an overpressure in excess of 250 PSI. 
Ammonia detectors are located in the following areas and alarm to the Mystic monitoring system:
Engine Room #3 (1)
Engine Room #3 Vent Line (1)

The Engine Room vent fans will turn on in the event of ammonia detection in the Engine Rooms, or if the break glass button outside the Engine Rooms is activated. The fan can be controlled within the mystic panel from a computer as well.
Should it become necessary to shut down all the compressors there is a break glass button (Emergency Refrigeration Stop) located next to the Emergency Fan/Ventilation Start button outside the Engine Rooms that will shut down all the compressors and ammonia pumps when activated. 


?
1.5.	Summary of Hazard Assessment
This hazard assessment was conducted to meet the RMP Off-site Consequence Analysis requirements for the ammonia refrigeration system. The only RMP regulated substance at this facility is anhydrous ammonia and is classified as a toxic substance, liquefied under pressure. The definitions and parameters for the following release scenarios are based on the RMP*Comp software calculations and described in Chapter 4: Off-site Consequence Analysis.

The worst-case release scenario (OCA-1) used in this assessment identifies the high-temperature recirculator (V-2) in Engine Room 4 as the vessel with the potential to hold the largest quantity of ammonia. This is based on the system design using this vessel as a pump-down holding receiver. The worst-case release scenario is based on over-filling this vessel causing the released quantity to be equal to the total vessel volume with no piping vo

lume included.
The alternative release scenario (OCA-2) is the direct release of ammonia vapor from the largest pressure relief valve. This scenario was chosen as the most probable source of an ammonia release that would have the potential of offsite consequences based on the number of relief valves and on the high summer operating pressures. The size of the release is based on the rated capacity of the pressure relief valve (86.6 lbs/min) having a worst-case release-duration of ten minutes.

1.6.	Accident History  Last Five Years
This facility has not had an RMP reportable incident in the last 5 years. 


1.7.	Planned Changes to improve safety
No changes are planned at this time.
?

2.0	MANAGEMENT PROGRAM
2.1.	Purpose 
This facility has developed a management system to oversee the implementation of the risk management program. 
Plant Manager
This is the person with overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the program. He/she is assisted by the Facilities Manager and/or Utilities Supervisor, and Environmental Manager, but the ultimate responsibility remains with the Plant Manager.  
The chart in Section 7 shows the specific duties of each position.
2.2.	Scope
The focus of the Management Program is on tracking, reporting, and documenting the operation and maintenance of the ammonia refrigeration system. This is done to insure maximum safety and to minimize risks to the community, the environment, the employees, and the facility.  Operations at the facility comply with all aspects of the PSM Progra

m.   
2.3.	Commitment
Management is fully committed to the Risk Management Program and sees it as a vital and integrated part of general operations.  Management does provide the support and the resources to implement these procedures on an ongoing basis. Furthermore, the company understands that it is important to convey its commitment to employees and supervisors.  Some of the ways that this will be accomplished are:
	by verbal instructions when employees are hired
	by strict enforcement of practices, procedures, and programs for operating and maintaining the ammonia refrigeration system  to insure safety 
	by the example of the site and corporate management
	by recognizing employees who excel in the RMP
	by training and drills 
Steps, such as these, demonstrate the commitment of corporate management to enforcing employee participation in and compliance with this RMP Program.  			
2.4.	Focus
The Facilities Manager has the responsibility to oversee 13 functional areas: 
	Employee participation
	Process safety information
	Process hazard analysis
	Standard operating procedures	
	Training
	Contractors
	Pre-startup review
	Mechanical integrity
	Hot work
	Management of change
	Incident investigation
	Emergency response plan
	Compliance audits
The Facilities Manager is involved in planning, staffing, and reviewing these areas and is charged with actively managing compliance with these regulations. These topics are described in more detail in Section 4, Accident Prevention Program, as noted in EPA 550-B-98-014.
2.5.	Audits and Reviews			
2.5.1.	Policy
The companys policy is to take federal regulations seriously, knowing that these regulations can protect life and property.  The Environmental Manager will review RMP compliance on an on-going basis. Section 7 of volume 14 outlines the responsibilities of management at this facility.
2.5.2.	Compliance Audits
The PSM Manager and their designees will conduct PSM compliance audits at least every three years f
or the entire program; annual reviews/updates will also be performed for various elements of the RMP by the Environmental Manager.
